facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 229 of 1970 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 229 of 1970.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated 29th September 1970 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 891 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: From the judgment and order dated the 29th September, 1970 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court at Hyderabad in Criminal Appeal No. 891 of 1969.

facts.text: Appellant charged with three brothers-in-law Bayyarapu Butchiah, Bayyarapu Chandriah, and Bayyarapu Kotayya under Sections 302, 325, and 323 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was charged, with his three brothers-in-law, Bayyarapu Butchiah, Bayyarapu Chandriah, and Bayyarapu Kotayya for offences punishable under Section 302, 325, and 323 Indian Penal

facts.text: Offence involved murder of Irlapati Ramayya, causing grievous hurt to Ankayya PW 2, and simple injury to China Veerayya PW 1.

anchor.surface_text: Irlapati Ramayya and causing grievous hurt to Ankayya, P.W. 2, and simple injury to China Veerayya, P.W. 1, at about 4.30 p.m., on 15-6-69, in front of house of Vipparla Peda Veerayya

facts.text: Incident occurred at about 4.30 p.m. on 15-6-1969 in front of house of Vipparla Peda Veerayya in Village Vipparla, District Guntur, Andhra Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: P.W. 1, at about 4.30 p.m., on 15-6-69, in front of house of Vipparla Peda Veerayya in Village Vipparla. District Guntur in the State of Andhra Pradesh.

facts.text: Sessions Judge of Guntur acquitted the accused.

anchor.surface_text: They were tried and acquitted by the learned Sessions Judge of Guntur who attached companysiderable importance to the supposed delay in lodging the First Information Report

facts.text: FIR lodged at 10.30 p.m. on 15-6-1969 at Police Station Sattonapalli, 13 miles from scene.

anchor.surface_text: of the alleged occurrence at 10.30 p.m. on 15-6-69 at Police Station, Sattonapalli, 13 miles away from the scene of the incident.

facts.text: Explanation for FIR delay: wife and relations busy getting medical attention for deceased.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution had a sufficiently good explanation for the supposed delay inasmuch as the wife and other relations of the deceased were busy trying to get adequate medical attention

facts.text: High Court convicted appellant under Section 302 to life imprisonment, and under 325 and 323 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court had, on an appeal to it, companysidered this and other questions involved in the case and companyvicted and sentenced the appellant under Section 302 to life imprisonment

facts.text: High Court convicted other three accused under Sections 323 and 324 IPC to fine of Rs. 150/- or 3 months RI.

anchor.surface_text: and awarded other appropriate sentences under Sections 325 and 323 I.P.C. to him. The High Court had companyvicted the three other company accused under Sections 323 and 324 I.P.C. only and had sentenced them to a fine of Rs. 150/- only,

facts.text: Witnesses gave varying times for occurrence between noon and just before sunset.

anchor.surface_text: Seventhly, we were taken through the statements of prosecution witnesses, P. W. 1, P.W. 2, P. W. 3, P. W. 4, W. 5, P.W. 6, as to the time of the occurrence which was variously stated by them to have taken place at different times between numbern and just before sunset.

facts.text: Variations in place where Ankayya PW2 beaten: 10-15 yds, 60-70 yds, 1-2 yds from house.

anchor.surface_text: Eightly, there were variations in the statements of witnesses about the time and place at which China Veerayya, P.W. I and Ankayya, P. W. 2, were said to have been beaten.

facts.text: Post mortem injuries on deceased: lacerated injury scalp 8 cm x 1 cm, cephalo hematoma, contusion left forearm, abrasions below right knee.

anchor.surface_text: with the post mortem report which described the injuries of Ramayya, deceased as follows Lacerated injury scalp 8 cm x I cm. placed over internal parietal area in anterior posterior direction. Cephalo hematoma present extending over left parietal,

facts.text: Scalp covered with blood, considerable bleeding.

anchor.surface_text: in fact, the Doctor said that the scalp was companyered with blood. Therefore, the attempt to explain the mysterious absence of any blood from the alleged place of occurrence is rather feeble.

facts.text: Dispute over possession and construction of house, 400 stones collected for repairs.

anchor.surface_text: We may also mention that the nature of the incident set up by the prosecution itself shows that there was a dispute over the possession and companystruction of a house for the repairs of which about 400 stones had been companylected.

facts.text: Constable came to village at about noon on day of occurrence.

anchor.surface_text: On an occasion prior to the actual occurrence, the appellant was said to have been obstructed from carrying stones. it was alleged that he had, for this reason, beaten Sayamma and her mother who were said to have obstructed him. A companystable was said to have companye to the village at about numbern oft the day of occurrence

facts.text: Village Munsif not informed about incident.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the features mentioned already, we find that the village Munsif, who was available for a companyplaint about the incident was number informed.

facts.text: Deceased not taken to nearest dispensary.

anchor.surface_text: This suggests that the party of the prosecution witnesses had something, like stone throwing by them, to hide. The deceased was also number taken to the nearest dispensary to get his wounds dressed.

facts.text: Supreme Court not satisfied that High Court rightly interfered with acquittal order.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, number satisfied that the High Court had rightly? interfered with the order of acquittal passed by the Trial Court.

It is well established that, in an appeal against acquittal, the appellate Court ought to attach due weight to the assessment of evidence by the Trial Court which has had the additional advantage of seeing the witnesses depose in the witness box.

holdings.text: The prosecution had a sufficiently good explanation for the supposed delay inasmuch as the wife and other relations of the deceased were busy trying to get adequate medical attention for the deceased before thinking of making the I.R.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution had a sufficiently good explanation for the supposed delay inasmuch as the wife and other relations of the deceased were busy trying to get adequate medical attention

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explanation that relations were busy securing medical aid for deceased accepted over Sessions Judge's emphasis

holdings.text: We do not think that the injuries alleged have been inflicted on the head with sticks are of such a nature that they would not produce considerable bleeding. in fact, the Doctor said that the scalp was covered with blood. Therefore, the attempt to explain the mysterious absence of any blood from the alleged place of occurrence is rather feeble.

anchor.surface_text: in fact, the Doctor said that the scalp was covered with blood. Therefore, the attempt to explain the mysterious absence of any blood from the alleged place of occurrence is rather feeble.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Medical evidence shows considerable bleeding expected from described injuries, inconsistent with no blood at scene

holdings.text: absence of blood from the alleged place of occurrence appears to us to carry a significance which the High Court ignored.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, absence of blood from the alleged place of occurrence appears to US to carry. a significance which the High Court ignored.
